functions package¶

Submodules¶

functions.email_service module¶

functions.email_service.send_tachycardia_email(df)¶

Sends an email to the attending physician

The email warns of a tachycardic heart rate and includes the patient ID, age, current heart rate, and the time that the heart rate was recorded.

Parameters:df (dict) – dictionary containing the tachycardic patient information and heart rate data.
Returns:None

functions.hr_calculations module¶

functions.hr_calculations.append_heart_rate(df, database)¶

Appends the input heart rate to the patient in the database

Parameters:
  • df (dict) – input dictionary of patient_id and heart_rate
  • database (list of dict) – list containing all patient data
Returns:

updates database to include the heart rate, also

return the index of the patient in the database so that the patient ID will not have to be found again for following calculations
Return type:

list of dict, int
functions.hr_calculations.average_heart_rate(heart_rates)¶

Calculate the average of a list of heart rates

Parameters:heart_rates (list) – a list of heart rates
Returns:the average heart rate
Return type:float
functions.hr_calculations.check_recent_timestamps(times, ref_time)¶

Checks if the input time is too recent and precludes all measurements

Parameters:
  • times (list) – list of times, in seconds float, in which recordings were made
  • ref_time (float) – input reference time in seconds
Returns:

returns True if there are more recent measurements than ref_time
Return type:

bool
functions.hr_calculations.create_timestamp()¶

Creates a timestamp for the heart rate measurement

Returns:date and time, eg. “2018-03-09 11:00:36.372339”
Return type:str

Parameters:

  • database (list of dict) – Contains all entered patients

functions.hr_calculations.find_index_larger(times, ref_time)¶

Returns the index of times whose value is just larger than ref_time

Parameters:
  • times (list) – A list of floats denoting a datestring in seconds
  • ref_time (float) – A input date in seconds
Returns:

the index which is just larger than ref_time
Return type:

int
functions.hr_calculations.get_date_as_numeric(date)¶

Takes the date as a string and returns it as a float The input date is converted to seconds for comparison with other dates

Parameters:
  • date (str) – the date as a string “%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f”,
  • "2018-03-09 11 (eg) – 00:36.372339”
Returns:

time in seconds
Return type:

float
functions.hr_calculations.get_heart_rates(p_id, database)¶

Takes a patient ID and returns all recorded heart rate information

Parameters:
  • p_id (str) – the patient ID to use for heart rate retrieval
  • database (list of dict) – the database containing all patient information
Returns:

a list of all heart rates recorded for a given patient
Return type:

list
functions.hr_calculations.get_times(p_id, database)¶

Retrieve the timestamps for each heart rate recorded

Parameters:
  • p_id (str) – a string identifying the patient
  • database (list of dict) – contains all patient data
Returns:

a list of timestamps pertaining to the patient
Return type:

list
functions.hr_calculations.hr_after_time(ref_time, timestamps, heart_rates)¶

Gather the heart rates after a reference point in time Converts string dates to a numeric in seconds, then checks that there are recorded values occurring after the reference time. Returns a list of heart rate measurements after ref_time.

Parameters:
  • ref_time (str) – the date and time as input by the user
  • timestamps (list) – a list of strings of the timestamps denoting when heart rate information was encountered.
  • heart_rates (list) – a list of recorded heart rates
Returns:

a list of heart rates recorded after ref_time
Return type:

list

is_tachycardic(patient_id, database)¶

Computes if the patient is tachycardic This function finds the patient in the datebase, grabs the last heart rate recorded, and uses the patient’s age to determine if the patient is tachycardic

Parameters:
  • patient_id (str) – patient identifier
  • database (list of dict) – a list of patients and their information
Returns:

True if the patient is tachycardic, false otherwise str: timestamp of last recorded heart rate
Return type:

bool

functions.verify_inputs module¶

functions.verify_inputs.check_date_format(date)¶

Checks the formatting of the posted date

The date should be in the format: “%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f” (eg. ‘2018-03-09 11:00:36.372339’). Returns False if this is not the case.

Parameters:date (str) – input date as a string
Returns:True is the date is in the correct format
Return type:bool
functions.verify_inputs.contains_key(required_key, df)¶

Checks if the required key is found in the input dictionary

Parameters:
  • required_key (str) – a required key
  • df (dict) – the input dictionary being checked
Returns:

True if the input contains the required key and False otherwise
Return type:

bool
functions.verify_inputs.hr_validation(hr)¶

Validates that the given heart rate is within physiological ranges

Source for heart rate bounds: https://iytmed.com/dangerous-heart-rate/

Parameters:hr (int) – input heart rate in bmp
Returns:Boolean returns True if heart rate is within possible bounds
Return type:bool
functions.verify_inputs.is_dictionary(df)¶

Determine if an input varible is a dictionary

Parameters:df – incoming dictionary
Returns:True if the input was a dictionary and False otherwise
Return type:bool
functions.verify_inputs.is_numeric(num)¶

Checks if the input variable is numeric

The function converts numeric strings and floats to int. If these processes fail, it returns a False flag which can be used for error handling.

Parameters:num (int or float or float) – input number
Returns:
True if the input is numeric, the input returned as an
integer
Return type:bool, int
functions.verify_inputs.patient_is_in_database(p_id, database)¶

This function searches the database for an input patient ID

Parameters:
  • p_id (str) – patient ID
  • database (list of dict) – list containing all patient and heart rate information
Returns:

Boolean value returns True if the patient is in the database
Return type:

bool
functions.verify_inputs.valid_email(email)¶

Check if entered email address is valid

This checks if the email address contains a “@” followed by a “.”

Parameters:email (str) – input email address
Returns:True if the input is a valid email and False otherwise
Return type:bool
functions.verify_inputs.verify_input_hr(df, database)¶

verifies that new heart rate information is in the correct format

This function tests that the input data is a dictionary, contains the required keys, has an existing patient ID, and that the heart rate is a valid integer.

Parameters:
  • df (dict) – input dictionary for a new patient
  • database (list of dict) – full list of patient data
Returns:

True if passes all tests
Return type:

bool
functions.verify_inputs.verify_input_internal_average(df, database)¶
verifies that the data structures posted to the input_internal_average
function is in the correct format

This function tests that the input data is a dictionary, contains the required keys, has a valid email, and that the patient’s age is a valid integer.

Parameters:
  • df (dict) – input dictionary for a new patient
  • database (list of dict) – full list of patient data
Returns:

True if passes all tests
Return type:

bool
functions.verify_inputs.verify_new_patient(df, database)¶

verifies that new patient information is in the correct format

This function tests that the input data is a dictionary, contains the required keys, has a valid email, and that the patient’s age is a valid integer.

Parameters:
  • df (dict) – input dictionary for a new patient
  • database (list of dict) – full list of patient data
Returns:

True if passes all tests
Return type:

bool
